To make the "Order Agora" button disappear when the screen hits the "Place Your Order" section, you can use JavaScript to add and remove a class to the button when the user scrolls to that section. Here's how you can do it:

  1. First, add a class to the "Order Agora" button, which we can use to show/hide it:
html
<div id="order-agora-container" class="order-agora-visible">
  <a href="#" class="cta" id="order-agora-btn">Order Agora</a>
</div>
  1. Next, add the following CSS to hide the button by default and show it when it has the "order-agora-visible" class:
css
#order-agora-container {
  display: none;
}

#order-agora-container.order-agora-visible {
  display: block;
  position: fixed;
  bottom: 20px;
  right: 20px;
  z-index: 999;
}
  1. Finally, add the following JavaScript code to handle the scrolling and toggle the class:
html
<script>
  window.addEventListener('scroll', function () {
    const orderSection = document.getElementById('order');
    const orderAgoraContainer = document.getElementById('order-agora-container');

    // Calculate the distance from the top of the page to the "Place Your Order" section
    const orderSectionTop = orderSection.getBoundingClientRect().top;

    // If the "Place Your Order" section is in the viewport, add the class to show the button
    if (orderSectionTop < window.innerHeight && orderSectionTop > 0) {
      orderAgoraContainer.classList.add('order-agora-visible');
    } else {
      // If the section is not in the viewport, remove the class to hide the button
      orderAgoraContainer.classList.remove('order-agora-visible');
    }
  });
</script>

Now, the "Order Agora" button should automatically disappear when the user scrolls to the "Place Your Order" section on the page. When the user scrolls away from that section, the button will reappear.

Apologies for the confusion. To make the "Order Agora" button appear only on the "Home," "Konaba Ami," and "Menu" sections, we need to modify the JavaScript code accordingly. We'll check if the user has scrolled to any of these sections, and if so, we'll show the button; otherwise, we'll hide it.

  1. First, add the class "hide-on-scroll" to the "Order Agora" button div to easily target it with JavaScript:
html
<div id="order-agora-container" class="order-agora-visible hide-on-scroll">
  <a href="#" class="cta" id="order-agora-btn">Order Agora</a>
</div>
  1. Next, modify the JavaScript code as follows:
html
<script>
  // Function to check if an element is in the viewport
  function isElementInViewport(el) {
    const rect = el.getBoundingClientRect();
    return (
      rect.top >= 0 &&
      rect.left >= 0 &&
      rect.bottom <= (window.innerHeight || document.documentElement.clientHeight) &&
      rect.right <= (window.innerWidth || document.documentElement.clientWidth)
    );
  }

  // Function to toggle the visibility of the "Order Agora" button
  function toggleOrderAgoraButton() {
    const orderAgoraContainer = document.getElementById('order-agora-container');
    const homeSection = document.getElementById('home');
    const konabaAmiSection = document.getElementById('about');
    const menuSection = document.getElementById('Menu');

    if (isElementInViewport(homeSection) || isElementInViewport(konabaAmiSection) || isElementInViewport(menuSection)) {
      orderAgoraContainer.classList.add('order-agora-visible');
    } else {
      orderAgoraContainer.classList.remove('order-agora-visible');
    }
  }

  // Event listeners for scroll and page load
  window.addEventListener('scroll', toggleOrderAgoraButton);
  window.addEventListener('load', toggleOrderAgoraButton);
</script>

Now, the "Order Agora" button will only appear on the "Home," "Konaba Ami," and "Menu" sections and will be hidden on other sections, including the "Place Your Order" section.

To hide the "Order Agora" button on the "Place Your Order" section and show it only on the "Home," "Konaba Ami," and "Menu" sections, we can use CSS. We'll utilize the class we added in the previous step ("hide-on-scroll") to hide the button when it's not required. Here's the CSS code to achieve that:

css
/* Add this CSS to hide the button by default */
.hide-on-scroll {
  display: none;
}

/* Add this CSS to show the button only when the class "order-agora-visible" is applied */
.order-agora-visible {
  display: block;
  position: fixed;
  bottom: 30px;
  right: 30px;
  background-color: #ff8800; /* Change the background color here */
  padding: 15px 25px;
  color: #fff;
  font-size: 18px;
  font-weight: 500;
  text-decoration: none;
  border-radius: 30px;
  box-shadow: 0px 3px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
  transition: opacity 0.3s ease;
}

.order-agora-visible:hover {
  opacity: 0.8;
}

/* Add media query to hide the button on smaller screens if necessary */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .order-agora-visible {
    display: none;
  }
}

In this CSS, we initially set the "Order Agora" button to be hidden by default using the .hide-on-scroll class. Then, we use the .order-agora-visible class to show the button when it's required. This class is added and removed dynamically by JavaScript based on the visibility of the respective sections ("Home," "Konaba Ami," and "Menu").

Additionally, the position: fixed property ensures that the button stays fixed on the screen while scrolling. You can change the background-color, padding, color, font-size, and other properties to customize the button's appearance according to your preference.

Make sure to add this CSS code inside the <style> tags in your HTML file, or you can also include it in your external CSS file.

so, still about the button Agora. can you make the button Agora Blink?
1 / 1

Sure, to make the "Order Agora" button blink, you can use CSS animations. Here's an example of how you can achieve the blinking effect:

HTML:

html
<div id="order-agora-container">
  <a href="#" class="cta" id="order-agora-btn">Order Agora</a>
</div>

CSS:

css
/* Add this CSS to your existing styles */

/* Keyframes for blinking animation */
@keyframes blink {
  0% { opacity: 1; }
  50% { opacity: 0; }
  100% { opacity: 1; }
}

/* Apply the blinking animation to the "Order Agora" button */
#order-agora-btn {
  animation: blink 1.5s infinite;
}

With this CSS code, the "Order Agora" button will blink continuously. You can adjust the animation duration (1.5s in this example) and the animation effect by modifying the @keyframes rule.

Apologies for the confusion. The @keyframes rule should be placed inside the existing CSS style block, like this:

css
/* Add this CSS to your existing styles */

/* Keyframes for blinking animation */
@keyframes blink {
  0% { opacity: 1; }
  50% { opacity: 0; }
  100% { opacity: 1; }
}

/* Apply the blinking animation to the "Order Agora" button */
#order-agora-btn {
  animation: blink 1.5s infinite;
}

You can add the @keyframes rule and the animation declaration for #order-agora-btn in the same <style> block where you have defined other styles for your page. Place it either in the <head> section of your HTML or directly within your HTML file inside a <style> tag.

Apologies for the oversight. The reason the link (href) doesn't work after adding the blinking animation is that the animation is interfering with the click event on the button. When an element has an active animation, it may affect its clickability.

To resolve this issue, we can add a wrapper around the button and apply the animation to the wrapper instead of directly to the button. Here's how you can do it:

HTML:

html
<div id="order-agora-container">
  <a href="#" class="cta" id="order-agora-btn">Order Agora</a>
</div>

CSS:

css
/* Add this CSS to your existing styles */

/* Keyframes for blinking animation */
@keyframes blink {
  0% { opacity: 1; }
  50% { opacity: 0; }
  100% { opacity: 1; }
}

/* Apply the blinking animation to the wrapper of "Order Agora" button */
#order-agora-container {
  animation: blink 1.5s infinite;
}

By applying the animation to the wrapper (#order-agora-container), we ensure that the clickability of the link is preserved. Now the button should blink and remain clickable as well.

It seems like you want to make the "Order Agora" button blink. Let's add the blinking animation to the button. Here's how you can do it:

  1. Add the keyframes and animation rule to your existing CSS:
css
/* Add this CSS to your existing styles */

/* Keyframes for blinking animation */
@keyframes blink {
  0% { opacity: 1; }
  50% { opacity: 0; }
  100% { opacity: 1; }
}

/* Apply the blinking animation to the "Order Agora" button */
#order-agora-btn {
  animation: blink 1.5s infinite;
}
  1. Add an ID to the "Order Agora" button in your HTML:
html
<!-- Add the "order-agora-btn" ID to the "Order Agora" button -->
<a href="#order" class="cta" id="order-agora-btn">Order Agora</a>

Now, when you open the HTML file in your browser, you should see the "Order Agora" button blinking. The link functionality should also work correctly.

Apologies for the oversight. It seems that the blinking effect caused the link functionality to stop working. We can fix this issue by adjusting the HTML and CSS slightly. The problem is that the position: fixed applied to the .cta button is causing it to overlay the other content and capture the click events, preventing the link from working.

Here's the updated code to resolve this issue:

HTML:

html
<!-- Update the "Order Agora" link to a button element instead of an anchor element -->
<button class="cta" onclick="scrollToOrder()">Order Agora</button>

CSS:

css
/* Add this CSS to your existing styles */

/* Apply the blinking animation to the "Order Agora" button */
.cta {
  animation: blink 1.5s infinite;
  position: relative; /* Add this line to ensure the button respects the document flow */
  z-index: 1; /* Add this line to ensure the button is above other content */
}

/* Add a higher z-index to the .navbar so it is above the .cta button */
.navbar {
  z-index: 2;
}

JavaScript:

javascript
// Add this JavaScript code to scroll to the order section when clicking the "Order Agora" button
function scrollToOrder() {
  const orderSection = document.getElementById("order");
  orderSection.scrollIntoView({ behavior: "smooth" });
}

With these changes, the "Order Agora" button should now be clickable, and the link functionality will work correctly along with the blinking effect. The JavaScript code will scroll to the "order" section smoothly when the button is clicked.

how set a picture only on some position using css '"position: ;"
1 / 1

To set a picture at a specific position using CSS, you can use the position property along with the top, right, bottom, and left properties to control the positioning of the image. Here are the possible values for the position property:

  1. static: The default value. The element will follow the normal document flow.
  2. relative: The element is positioned relative to its normal position in the document flow, and you can use top, right, bottom, and left to adjust its position relative to its normal position.
  3. absolute: The element is removed from the normal document flow and positioned relative to its nearest positioned ancestor. If no positioned ancestor is found, it is positioned relative to the initial containing block (typically the viewport).
  4. fixed: The element is removed from the normal document flow and positioned relative to the initial containing block. It will stay fixed in the same position even when the user scrolls the page.
  5. sticky: The element is positioned based on the user's scroll position. It behaves like relative until it reaches a specified threshold, then it becomes fixed.

Here's an example of setting a picture at a specific position using the position property:

HTML:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Positioning Example</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <div class="container">
        <img src="path_to_your_image.jpg" alt="Image">
    </div>
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

css
body {
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;
}

.container {
    position: relative; /* Set the container to relative position */
    width: 100%;
    height: 100vh;
}

img {
    position: absolute; /* Set the image to absolute position */
    top: 50px; /* Distance from the top of the container */
    left: 20px; /* Distance from the left of the container */
    width: 200px;
    height: 150px;
}

In this example, the image will be positioned 50 pixels from the top and 20 pixels from the left of its containing div with the class "container." You can adjust the values of top, right, bottom, and left properties to position the image as per your requirement.

how about i just want show only on some section... what command should use?

If you want to show an image only on specific sections of your webpage, you can achieve that by adding the image as a background image to the desired section using CSS. By using the background-image property, you can set a background image for any element. Here's how you can do it:

Assuming you want to show the image only in the "home" section, "Menu" section, and "contact" section:

HTML:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- ... Your head content ... -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
    <section class="hero" id="home">
        <!-- Your hero section content here -->
    </section>
    <section id="about" class="about">
        <!-- Your about section content here -->
    </section>
    <section id="Menu" class="Menu" style="background-image: url('path_to_your_image.jpg')">
        <!-- Your Menu section content here -->
    </section>
    <section class="order" id="order">
        <!-- Your order section content here -->
    </section>
    <section id="contact" class="contact" style="background-image: url('path_to_your_image.jpg')">
        <!-- Your contact section content here -->
    </section>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

css
/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

/* For the sections where you want the background image to show */
#Menu, #contact {
    /* Set the height and other styles for the sections as needed */
    height: 100vh;
    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-size: cover;
    background-position: center;
}

/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

In the above example, we are setting the background image for the "Menu" and "contact" sections directly in the HTML using inline styles (style="background-image: url('path_to_your_image.jpg')") to show the image only in these two sections.

You can apply the same approach to other sections where you want the background image to appear. Remember to adjust the path_to_your_image.jpg with the actual path to your image file.

ok cool... so how to add the code for image? on CSS and HTML
1 / 1

To add an image to your webpage using both CSS and HTML, you can use the img HTML element and style it using CSS. Here's how you can do it:

HTML:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- ... Your head content ... -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
    <section class="hero" id="home">
        <!-- Your hero section content here -->
        <img src="path_to_your_image.jpg" alt="Description of the image">
    </section>
    <section id="about" class="about">
        <!-- Your about section content here -->
    </section>
    <section id="Menu" class="Menu">
        <!-- Your Menu section content here -->
        <img src="path_to_your_image.jpg" alt="Description of the image">
    </section>
    <section class="order" id="order">
        <!-- Your order section content here -->
    </section>
    <section id="contact" class="contact">
        <!-- Your contact section content here -->
        <img src="path_to_your_image.jpg" alt="Description of the image">
    </section>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

css
/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

/* For the sections where you want the image to be displayed */
#home img, #Menu img, #contact img {
    /* Adjust the image styles as needed */
    display: block; /* Ensures the image is treated as a block element */
    width: 100%; /* Adjust the width of the image */
    max-width: 500px; /* Set a maximum width to avoid stretching on larger screens */
    margin: 0 auto; /* Centers the image horizontally within the section */
}

/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

In the above example, we added the img element within the respective sections where you want to display the image. You can adjust the path_to_your_image.jpg with the actual path to your image file. The alt attribute provides a description of the image, which is important for accessibility and SEO purposes.

In the CSS part, we targeted the img elements within the sections with the IDs "home," "Menu," and "contact," and applied some basic styles. You can modify the styles to fit your specific design requirements. The styles in this example will make the image display as a block element, set its width to 100% (of its container), and center it horizontally within the section. Additionally, we've set a maximum width of 500px to prevent the image from becoming too large on larger screens.

If you want to add a button to specific sections and style it differently based on the section, you can follow a similar approach. First, you'll add the button element to the HTML sections where you want the button to appear. Then, you can use CSS to style the button differently for each section.

Here's an example of how you can do this:

HTML:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- ... Your head content ... -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
    <section class="hero" id="home">
        <!-- Your hero section content here -->
        <button class="cta">Order Now</button>
    </section>
    <section id="about" class="about">
        <!-- Your about section content here -->
        <button class="cta">Learn More</button>
    </section>
    <section id="Menu" class="Menu">
        <!-- Your Menu section content here -->
        <button class="cta">View Menu</button>
    </section>
    <section class="order" id="order">
        <!-- Your order section content here -->
        <button class="cta">Place Your Order</button>
    </section>
    <section id="contact" class="contact">
        <!-- Your contact section content here -->
        <button class="cta">Contact Us</button>
    </section>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

css
/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

/* For the sections where you want the button to be displayed */
#home .cta {
    /* Adjust the button styles for the home section */
    background-color: #b6895b;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.6rem;
    padding: 1rem 2rem;
}

#about .cta {
    /* Adjust the button styles for the about section */
    background-color: #4a90e2;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.6rem;
    padding: 1rem 2rem;
}

#Menu .cta {
    /* Adjust the button styles for the Menu section */
    background-color: #45a65d;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.6rem;
    padding: 1rem 2rem;
}

#order .cta {
    /* Adjust the button styles for the order section */
    background-color: #d62e2e;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.6rem;
    padding: 1rem 2rem;
}

#contact .cta {
    /* Adjust the button styles for the contact section */
    background-color: #d68b2e;
    color: #fff;
    font-size: 1.6rem;
    padding: 1rem 2rem;
}

/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

In this example, we added the button element within each section where you want the button to appear. We also added the class cta to each button to distinguish it as a call-to-action button.

In the CSS part, we used CSS selectors to target each button within its respective section based on the section's ID. Then, we applied different styles to the button for each section. You can customize the button's appearance by modifying the button styles under each section ID. The styles in this example include different background colors, text colors, font size, and padding for each button. Feel free to adjust these styles to match your design preferences.

Sure! To create a code that tracks the selected menu items and shows the total amount of items and the total price on the #order section, we can use JavaScript to handle the logic.

Here's an example of how you can achieve this:

HTML:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- ... Your head content ... -->
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
    <section class="order" id="order">
        <h2>Place Your Order</h2>
        <form id="order-form">
            <div class="menu-item">
                <input type="checkbox" id="menu-item-1" name="menu-item" value="Menu Item 1">
                <label for="menu-item-1">Menu Item 1 - $10</label>
            </div>
            <div class="menu-item">
                <input type="checkbox" id="menu-item-2" name="menu-item" value="Menu Item 2">
                <label for="menu-item-2">Menu Item 2 - $15</label>
            </div>
            <!-- Add more menu items here -->

            <button type="submit" class="cta">Place Order</button>
        </form>
        <div id="order-summary">
            <p>Total Items: <span id="total-items">0</span></p>
            <p>Total Price: $<span id="total-price">0</span></p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <!-- ... Your other HTML content ... -->
    <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

css
/* ... Your existing CSS styles ... */

JavaScript (script.js):

javascript
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    const orderForm = document.getElementById('order-form');
    const totalItemsSpan = document.getElementById('total-items');
    const totalPriceSpan = document.getElementById('total-price');
    const menuItems = orderForm.querySelectorAll('input[name="menu-item"]');
    let totalItems = 0;
    let totalPrice = 0;

    orderForm.addEventListener('change', updateOrderSummary);

    function updateOrderSummary() {
        totalItems = 0;
        totalPrice = 0;

        menuItems.forEach(item => {
            if (item.checked) {
                totalItems++;
                totalPrice += parseInt(item.dataset.price);
            }
        });

        totalItemsSpan.textContent = totalItems;
        totalPriceSpan.textContent = totalPrice;
    }

    orderForm.addEventListener('submit', function(event) {
        event.preventDefault();
        alert('Order placed successfully!\nTotal Items: ' + totalItems + '\nTotal Price: $' + totalPrice);
        // You can perform additional actions here, such as sending the order to a server.
    });

    // Initialize the order summary when the page loads
    updateOrderSummary();
});

In this example, we added a form with multiple checkboxes representing menu items in the #order section. Each checkbox has a value attribute representing the menu item's name and a data-price attribute representing its price.

We used JavaScript to handle the logic of calculating the total number of items selected and the total price of the selected items. The updateOrderSummary function is responsible for updating the total items and total price whenever a menu item checkbox is selected or deselected. The function is called on the form's change event.

The order summary is displayed in the #order-summary section below the form. The total items and total price are updated in the respective span elements with the IDs total-items and total-price.

When the user submits the form (by clicking the "Place Order" button), an alert is displayed with the total number of items and the total price. You can modify this behavior to perform additional actions, such as sending the order to a server for processing.

Note: In this example, the menu item prices are hard-coded in the HTML using the data-price attribute. In a real-world scenario, you would likely retrieve the menu item data and prices from a server or database.

To add CSS to your website, you can follow these steps:

  1. Create a new CSS file: In your project folder, create a new file named "style.css" and save it in the "css" folder (assuming you have a folder named "css" for CSS files).

  2. Link the CSS file to your HTML: In the <head> section of your HTML file, add a link to your CSS file using the <link> tag.

  3. Write your CSS styles: Open the "style.css" file you created and start adding your CSS styles to customize your website's appearance.

Here's an example of how to do it:

i want you to add the display the toal items and total price right before submit order, help me wrote the code for that
1 / 1

Sure, I can help you display the total items and total price before submitting the order. To achieve this, we will need to add some JavaScript code to calculate the total items and total price based on the selected menu items.

First, let's modify your existing HTML code to add a new section right before the "Submit Order" button, where we will display the total items and total price:

html
<!-- ... Your existing code ... -->

<section class="order" id="order">
    <!-- ... Your existing code ... -->

    <!-- Add the order summary section -->
    <div id="order-summary">
        <p>Total Items: <span id="total-items">0</span></p>
        <p>Total Price: $<span id="total-price">0</span></p>
    </div>

    <!-- Add the "Submit Order" button -->
    <button type="submit" class="btn">Submit Order</button>
</section>

<!-- ... Your existing code ... -->

Now, let's add the JavaScript code to calculate the total items and total price based on the selected menu items. Place the following JavaScript code at the end of your HTML file, just before the closing </body> tag:

html
<!-- ... Your existing code ... -->

<script>
  // Function to update the order summary
  function updateOrderSummary() {
    const checkboxes = document.querySelectorAll('.menu-item input[type="checkbox"]');
    let totalItems = 0;
    let totalPrice = 0;

    checkboxes.forEach((checkbox) => {
      if (checkbox.checked) {
        totalItems++;
        // Assuming each item has a price defined in a data attribute like data-price="2.00"
        totalPrice += parseFloat(checkbox.dataset.price);
      }
    });

    const totalItemsElement = document.getElementById('total-items');
    const totalPriceElement = document.getElementById('total-price');

    totalItemsElement.textContent = totalItems;
    totalPriceElement.textContent = totalPrice.toFixed(2); // Display the price with two decimal places
  }

  // Event listener for checkbox changes
  const checkboxes = document.querySelectorAll('.menu-item input[type="checkbox"]');
  checkboxes.forEach((checkbox) => {
    checkbox.addEventListener('change', updateOrderSummary);
  });

  // Initial update of the order summary
  updateOrderSummary();
</script>

</body>
</html>

Make sure to adjust the data-price attribute in each menu item checkbox to reflect the correct price for that item. For example:

html
<div class="menu-item">
    <input type="checkbox" id="beefy" name="items[]" value="Beefy" data-price="2.00">
    <label for="beefy">Beefy - USD 2.00</label>
</div>

This JavaScript code will calculate the total items and total price whenever a menu item checkbox is checked or unchecked, and it will display the updated values in the "order-summary" section.

Now, when you select different menu items, the total items and total price will be dynamically updated accordingly. When you submit the order, the form will be submitted to the "submit_order.php" file as defined in the action attribute of the <form> tag.

can you make the total price and total item as responsive as i want, when we tick the the checkbox the total price and total items response automatically to the amount of tick and price we selected
1 / 1

To make the total price and total items responsive and automatically update based on the checkboxes selected, we'll need to use JavaScript. We'll attach event listeners to the checkboxes and update the total price and total items whenever a checkbox is checked or unchecked.

Here's the updated HTML with some changes to add IDs to the checkboxes:

html
<!-- Your existing HTML code ... -->

<section class="order" id="order">
    <!-- Your existing form code ... -->

    <!-- Add the order summary section -->
    <div id="order-summary" class="order-summary">
        <p>Total Items: <span id="total-items">0</span></p>
        <p>Total Price: $<span id="total-price">0</span></p>
    </div>
</section>

<!-- Your existing HTML code ... -->

Now, let's add JavaScript to handle the checkbox updates and calculate the total items and total price:

html
<!-- Your existing HTML code ... -->

<script>
  // Function to update the order summary
  function updateOrderSummary() {
    const checkboxes = document.querySelectorAll('input[type="checkbox"]');
    let totalItems = 0;
    let totalPrice = 0;

    checkboxes.forEach((checkbox) => {
      if (checkbox.checked) {
        // Increment totalItems by 1 for each checked checkbox
        totalItems += 1;

        // Get the price of the checked checkbox from its data-price attribute
        const price = parseFloat(checkbox.getAttribute('data-price'));
        totalPrice += price;
      }
    });

    // Update the total items and total price on the page
    document.getElementById('total-items').textContent = totalItems;
    document.getElementById('total-price').textContent = totalPrice.toFixed(2);
  }

  // Attach event listeners to checkboxes to update the order summary on change
  const checkboxes = document.querySelectorAll('input[type="checkbox"]');
  checkboxes.forEach((checkbox) => {
    checkbox.addEventListener('change', updateOrderSummary);
  });

  // Initial update of the order summary when the page loads
  updateOrderSummary();
</script>

<!-- Your existing HTML code ... -->

With this JavaScript code, the total items and total price will automatically update whenever you check or uncheck a checkbox. The updateOrderSummary function calculates the total items and total price based on the checked checkboxes and then updates the respective elements on the page.

This implementation will ensure that the total items and total price are responsive and dynamically change as you select or deselect items.
